head.title: No Panic. No Shame. Just Doing a Job.

hedline.hl1: No Panic. No Shame. Just Doing a Job.

abstract.p: Publicity about attention deficit disorder and its cousin, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder has made more people aware of their condition; they also have new legal protections against job discrimination and access to new treatments; they have become much more open about forming strategies for dealing with disability on the job; more of them are also getting advice from personal coaches; John Schumacher comments on how his life has changed since learning he had attention deficit disorder; photo (M)

block.p: In her new job as a recruiter for a telecommunications company in Herndon, Va., Alicia Dennis was told to sign up for a weeklong training session. Ms. Dennis, who has attention deficit disorder, promptly panicked.

''I knew I'd never make it through,'' she said. ''It's very technical information. You're sitting in a lecture with 25 or 30 people looking at black-and-white slide presentations. I wouldn't be able to concentrate. I'd zone out, and then I'd be lost.''

''I knew I'd never make it through,'' she said. ''It's very technical information. You're sitting in a lecture with 25 or 30 people looking at black-and-white slide presentations. I wouldn't be able to concentrate. I'd zone out, and then I'd be lost.''

A decade ago, Ms. Dennis probably would have forced herself to go to the seminar, struggled through the classes and returned a nervous wreck. She might not have even known she suffered from A.D.D. -- or would have tried to keep it secret if she did know.

But times have changed. Publicity about A.D.D. and its cousin, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., has made many people with the disorders more aware of their condition. They also have new legal protections against job discrimination and access to new treatments. As a result, they have become much more open about forming strategies for dealing with the disability on the job.

More of them are also getting advice from personal coaches. The International Coach Federation says it found in an informal survey of its members that the number of their clients with A.D.D. had grown by an average of two-thirds in the last three years. Ms. Dennis is one such client. She told her supervisors about her condition before going to the training conference last year, and they agreed to let her take breaks from classes as needed and return later for makeup sessions. She has since hired a coach, Jodi Sleeper-Triplett, who, like other career coaches who specialize in attention disorders, says training can do wonders.

''My clients don't know where to start,'' Ms. Sleeper-Triplett said. ''They call me to ask: 'How do I figure out what time to get up in the morning so I can get to the office by 9? How do I set up a filing system so I can find things?' Managers and co-workers think the person doesn't care, or is rude. It really is a lack of knowledge and training.''

Ms. Sleeper-Triplett helps them develop systems to be better organized, like keeping detailed daily planners, setting alarms and beepers to remind them of appointments and color-coding their files. She also asks them to send her their to-do lists every day by e-mail, and she makes sure they have set aside enough time to complete each task.

Nancy Ratey, a coach from Wellesley, Mass., who herself has A.D.H.D., once counseled a doctor with the disorder who had performed well until his practice was taken over by managed care and he was forced to see many more patients. Overwhelmed, he took to chaining his foot to his desk to force himself to dictate revisions in patients' charts. Still, he fell behind with a backlog of more than 300 charts and was close to losing his job. Ms. Ratey advised him to stand up and move around while he dictated patient notes and to minimize interruptions by closing his office door and having papers put in a box outside the office. Within days, he had caught up.

Wilma Fellman, a career counselor in Troy, Mich., reports a similar rescue mission. She was working with a criminal lawyer with A.D.D. who was crumbling under the strain of juggling several cases at once. She persuaded him to switch to another specialty, real estate. ''He needed to work on one thing until he completed it,'' Ms. Fellman said. ''This area let him work on a case for a relatively short period of time and close it. He loved it.''

Experts say employers have everything to gain from the new openness about attention disorders, which are biochemical imbalances in the brain with symptoms that include procrastination, impulsiveness, disorganization, hyperactivity, lack of motivation and an inability to manage time. Once considered to afflict only children, the disorders are now said to have been diagnosed in 3 percent to 5 percent of adults, too. Half are women, who tend to feel the loss of self-esteem more keenly than men and who are often shunted into low-level administrative positions for which they are ill-suited, according to Dr. Kathleen Nadeau, a clinical psychologist in Silver Spring, Md.

Many counselors and other specialists say that in most cases, little things can make a big difference. Patricia H. Latham, a lawyer in Washington and co-founder of the National Center for Law and Learning Disabilities, says A.D.D. sufferers can negotiate minor accommodations in the workplace without disclosing that they have the disorder. They can ask for flexible start times, for example, or the right to close the office door if they are distracted by noise.

Nessa Miller, 40, an operations specialist for the Social Security Administration in Baltimore, decided to tell her employer of her A.D.H.D. diagnosis to help explain why she had temper tantrums so severe that she sometimes put her fists through walls. Her boss granted her extra breaks so she could get up from her desk and walk around for several minutes once an hour, and he began sending her memos with widely spaced paragraphs following up and summarizing his spoken instructions. Now, she says, she has learned to have a sense of humor about her condition. ''You have to learn it's not your fault,'' she said.

If fine-tuning the office routine does not work, specialists say, people with the disorders might want to think about switching careers. They tend to adapt well to jobs that require a lot of action, give immediate feedback and have clear deadlines, like sales, teaching, coaching sports, journalism, police work and acting, the specialists say. But they can become frustrated in jobs that require great attention to detail or sitting at a desk all day. ''Because A.D.D. people have trouble motivating themselves, they use external deadlines like Damocles' sword,'' said Dr. Barry Garfinkel, a child and adolescent psychiatrist in Minneapolis.

Often, the simple act of finding that the discomfort of a lifetime has a name is enough to start on the path to recovery. ''All my life I was a bad person,'' said John Schumacher, 53, a chef and hotel owner in New Prague, Minn. ''My nickname in school was Johnny Nothing. I was so frustrated, so ashamed, I'd put my head in my desk and cry.'' That changed after he was told that he had A.D.H.D. and was treated with medication. ''I have a whole new world,'' he said. ''I'm excited about life.''
